entry.title: UX with the Fam: Clean vs Clear
entry.content:
UX with the Fam will be an ongoing series that relates stories about UX (User Experience).

A few weeks ago my mom asked me how to take a picture using her phone. She had recently upgraded from a phone that ran Android 4.0 with Sony’s custom UI to a phone that ran stock Android 4.4. The image below depicts the interface that she saw on her new phone. She managed to take videos, but wasn’t able to take a picture.

My mom’s previous phone’s camera interface had an icon depicting a camera, similar to the one on the bottom right of the above image, but without the circular arrow. She knew on her old phone that when she pressed that button it took a picture. Not having this same icon on her new phone, she switched between pressing the bottom right button (which toggled the camera being used from rear-facing to front-facing) and the top left button (which started recording video).

I explained that she could take a picture by tapping anywhere on the screen, except on the icons. Not really intuitive.

How was she suppose to know? I think the very first time the camera app is launched it provides an overlay of instructions explaining that you tap the screen to snap a picture. The problem is that if you don’t initially use the camera app enough to imprint the actions needed, you may forget and resort to your previous mental model. It’s a case of trying to remember vs recognize. Remembering is much harder!

Trading clear signifiers for a “cleaner” design is generally not a good idea. Good design should be aesthetic and unobtrusive, but not at the expense of being understandable.

Note: It appears that Android 5.0 does have a signifier (the camera icon) for taking a pictures within the camera app. At least this is the case with my Dad’s Nexus 5.

entry.title: Vim and the Art of Text Manipulation
entry.content:
Last year (2014) I was looking to increase my text editing productivity and had the time to take the upfront productivity hit to learn Emacs or Vim. Initially I started learning Emacs since it integrates well with existing Unix tools and I could basically “live” in Emacs for most things… However, I really dislike the use of key chords for most operations. If you’re not familiar with key chords, it simply means holding one or more keys down while pressing another( e.g Ctrl+C, Alt+F4). So, I turned to Vim, which takes a modal approach (i.e. switching between different modes: normal, insert, visual, command etc to accomplish tasks). Vim’s modal approach employees single key and key sequences to perform operations, instead of key chords. This proved to be a much better approach for me and my inflexible fingers.

Note: Emacs has packages (e.g evil) that support Vim keybindings. I may move to this type of setup at some point…

So is Learning Vim (or Emacs) really worth it?

Someone who spends at least 30 - 40 deliberate hours of learning/practicing Vim (or Emacs) on average will be significantly more productive at text editing. So, if you spend a lot time editing, you should at least give it a try. You can take incremental steps so as not to completely tank your productivity.

Here’s a Stackoverflow question with many answers on Is learning Vim worth the effort?

Check out the videos below to get a quick idea of the things you can do with Vim and Emacs. Note: These aren’t tutorials taking you from step one. They are just videos to let you see a small bit of what is possible.

  • Learn to love the Vim text editor
  • Emacs Rocks! Episode 01: From var to this

Learning Vim

I was lucky enough to find a great piece of “edutainment” software for learning Vim last year - Vim Adventures (VA). VA describes itself as the “Zelda meets text editing” game. Comparisons to Zelda are probably a bit much, but Vim Adventures is a great way to learn the basics of Vim. The game engages you in a quest that has you repeating more than 60 Vim commands and motions that build up your muscle memory very fast. I felt significantly more productive using Vim after a week of playing VA.

My Recommended Resources for Getting Started with Vim

  1. vimtutor - If you’re on OSX or Linux, you can type vimtutor in a terminal to start the built-in Vim tutor. Windows users can install gVim and run the tutorial as well.
  2. Vim Adventures
  3. Seven habits of effective text editing - Tips from the Vim creator himself
  4. Learn to speak vim - verbs, nouns, and modifiers!
  5. The grammar of vim - Similar to the previous article

Other editors

There are a lot of text editors available besides Vim and Emacs (yeah, Emacs is more of an OS than just a text editor) that allow people to be very productive. The important thing is to learn your editor and become proficient in using it. If you think it’s lacking in features, you may want to explore other options.

entry.title: UX with the Fam - Part 1
entry.content:
UX with the Fam will be an ongoing series that relates stories about UX (User Experience).

The Issue

My dad has had a Nexus 5 since it came out in 2013. He mostly uses it to talk and text, but he also enjoys using Google Now to get information. A few weeks ago he asked me why his phone no longer audibly spelled-out words that he asked it to spell. He demonstrated what was happening - OK Google, spell embarrass. Google returned search results for spell embarrass, with the first result being merriam-webster’s entry for embarrass. Just as he said, there wasn’t an audible spelling of embarrass as he expected.

What was happening?

I first assumed that something had changed with his recent upgrade to Android 5.0. I decided to try out OK Google, spell embarrass on my phone, since it was still at 4.4. My phone returned the same merriam-webster entry without the word embarrass audibly spelled. Hmm… maybe spell wasn’t the right thing to say and I tried OK Google, how do you spell embarrass? - which did result in the word being spelled out. I must have used a similar phrase when I first showed him this feature. It seems we had both forgot the magic phrase…

User Expectations

My dad expected to hear the word spelled-out, but didn’t use the “correct” phrase. He assumed it didn’t matter which phrase was used as long as the same basic meaning was conveyed. This is a reasonable expectation. I explained that natural language processing(NLP) is not trivial and it’s very impressive what Google and other companies have accomplished with speech recognition and NLP. With that said, I don’t think this was case of being technically hard, but more likely an oversight, side effect or possibly intentional. After all, Google was returning a dictionary entry for embarrass when spell embarrass was used, not something unrelated. It should also be noted that how do you spell… is not the only phrase that can be used to get an audible spelling of a word, give me the spelling for the word… also results in the word being audibly spelled.

A better UX?

Providing consistent and predictable behavior is part of good user centered design. Predictable behavior results in the user being satisfied that the product/service is working reliably. Inconsistent behavior delays the user from their intended goal, which can be frustrating.

So providing a consistent experience for semantically similar queries (e.g. spell embarrass, how do you spell embarrass) is ideal. Realizing NLP isn’t perfect, Google and other companies using voice recognition/NLP could allow users to opt-in to a program to help identify semantically similar phrases. As an example, after saying OK Google, spell embarrass and providing the result, it could ask does “spell embarrass” have the same meaning as “how do you spell embarrass”. With enough responses in the affirmative, the phrase could be grouped with other phrases as being semantically equivalent and provide consistent behavior.
